Abstract: This paper explores the life and contributions of a pioneering woman scientist in the field of psychophysics, focusing on her groundbreaking research in color vision, hyperacuity, stereopsis, and trajectory motion. Her work has significantly advanced our understanding of visual perception and has led to new treatments for amblyopia. Through an autobiographical lens, the paper highlights the challenges and triumphs of her career, offering insights into the scientific process and the importance of perseverance in the face of adversity.
